title: High-End Sales in the Hamptons Drop to Six-Year Low
text:
High taxes are stifling sales and causing a buildup of supply in the tony Long Island, New York, enclave of the Hamptons, according to a report Thursday from Douglas Elliman.



Last year’s federal tax reform effectively eliminated state and local tax— or SALT—deductions for high-income earners and effectively raised the cost of living and owning a home in places such as New York, New Jersey, Connecticut and California.



More: A Cap d’Antibes Villa That Accents the Vistas of the French Riviera

The new tax code limited the SALT deduction to $10,000, when it was previously unlimited.



During the third quarter, homes priced at $5 million or more saw the fewest number of sales in six-and-a-half years, the brokerage said, though it did not provide exact statistics.



The wider luxury market—defined by Douglas Elliman as the top 10% of the market—-saw sales drop 14.6% in the third quarter compared to the same time last year. Across the overall market at all price points, transactions fell 15.2% in the same period.



At the same time, inventory soared at both the high end and in the overall market, up 143.4% and 76.9%, respectively.



“Right now in the Hamptons, it's all about pricing—at every level,” Todd Bourgard, Douglas Elliman’s senior executive regional manager of sales for the Hamptons, said in the report.

“Smart sellers are starting to understand that if they price a property properly, it will sell faster. As a result, we are extremely busy right now, and seeing a dramatic leap in multiple buyers on a single property, presenting full price offers or even above. Concurrently, both buyers and sellers are getting results at a fair market value,” Mr. Bourgard said.



Sellers’ willingness to negotiate—reflected in an increased discount of 12.3%, up from 10.5% at the same time last year—along with the sharp drop in mortgage rates has helped offset the negative effect of the SALT tax, and push up overall median prices, according to the report.



While the median sales price rose 5.5% to $857,000 on the luxury side, prices dropped 11.1% to $6 million.
